title: Co-op Group back on track
text:
Co-op Group back on track Co-op Group back on track THE Co-operative Group’s efforts to rebuild after the near-collapse of its bank and a management overhaul have borne early fruit as it swung back into the black in the first half. PUBLISHED: 21:39, Thu, Sep 3, 2015 | UPDATED: 21:44, Thu, Sep 3, 2015 PH Chief executive Richard Pennycook 
The mutual was boosted by strong trading in its food and funeralcare businesses as it posted a £36million profit compared with a £9million loss a year ago. 
Revenue was slightly lower at £4.6billion. 
But it warned that ongoing investment in new stores, IT systems and staff pay meant it would only break even, or make a small loss, for the full year. 
It has completed the rescue phase of its three-stage turnaround after selling its pharmacy and farms businesses, which helped it to a £124million pre-tax profit last year compared with a £2.3billion loss in 2013. 
It is now modernising the business after years of underinvestment. Our customers and members are beginning to see the difference Chief executive Richard Pennycook 
Chief executive Richard Pennycook said: “We’ve made a good start on the three-year journey to rebuild the Co-operative Group. 
“These early days are about fixing the basics – putting in place new leadership teams and providing the investment to deliver the strategies for our businesses. 
"Our customers and members are beginning to see the difference.” 
Chairman Allan Leighton said commercial improvements went hand in hand with moves to strengthen the board and management teams. 
Reforms were pushed through after its previous management was labelled “dysfunctional” by former City minister Lord Myners, who oversaw a review of the business. 
The Co-op increased its capital spending from £97million to £144million in the first half as it opened 35 new food stores and 10 funeral homes. 
Sales across its food business rose 0.8 per cent and underlying profit jumped 21 per cent to £120.4million, with its convenience stores enjoying 3.3 per cent higher turnover. 
It plans to open 60 new convenience stores and complete 150 refurbishments. 
Funeralcare had its busiest start to a year since 2008, with profit up by nearly 50 per cent to £51.8million on 16 per cent higher sales of £216.4million. 
Its insurance operation had a £500,000 profit from a £6.8million loss last time, while the bank in which it holds a 20 per cent stake was £204.2million in the red. Related articles
